Herodotus on Ecbatana(currently overbuilt by modern Hamadân)
the first circle the battlements are **white,
of the second **black,
of the third crimson,
of the fourth blue,
of the fifth red ... two last have their battlements
one of them overlaid with silver
and the other with gold

Rang/range = color

වර්ණ (varṇa) << barba, barva, Farbe!!
𓇋 𓁹 𓏏 𓅂 𓈒 𓏥||blue, colour, blue mineral ?|färbt

Many hieroglyphs are coloured, though the paint has worn off most stone inscriptions. Colors vary, but many glyphs are predominantly one colour or another, or a particular combination (such as red on the top and blue on the bottom). In some cases, two graphically similar glyphs may be distinguished solely by colour, though in other cases it's not known if the choice of colour had any meaning.

The Polychrome Hieroglyph Research Project

well attested color words:

𓈎 𓈖 𓇋 𓇋 𓐏 | be yellow (of eyes) | ⋍ ξανθός (xanthós) Ξανθός ⇔ citron κίτρινος ˈcitrinos +++

Universal colors

Some colors are intrinsically universally connected to colors.
These connections are often found in words:

SUN red-orange-gold-yellow-white-bright

𓇳 RAᵈ ≈ red 日 rì radiant ἀργός ṛjrá shining ☼ Sára™ सूर sū́ra સૂર્ય sū́rya 𑀲𑀽𑀭𑁆𑀬 "sun" sary sarı™ "yellow" ⇔ sárga vs sar=green
☼ Sára ≈ шара улаан šara ulaan "orange" цӏеран бос c̣eran bos
☼ Sára™ ≈ 𓋴 𓈙 𓊪 𓇳, 𓋴 𓈙 𓊪 𓇶 sśafra 𓊏 𓊪 𓇳, 𓊏 𓊪 𓇶 zafrā ዘፍራ "yellow, white, bright" swift 𒌓 Šamaš 𒀭𒌓 ≈ shimmer ≈ sun
𒌓 Šamaš ⇔ 𒅆𒅎𒌈 ši-im-tum šimtu simṭu šindu 𒅆𒅎𒌈 𒅊 /šindu arqu/ “yellow paint”
🌞 sun ≈ σανδαράχη sandarákhē σανδαράκινος sandarákinos "orange"
🌞 sun ≈ suwayan ᠰᡠᠸᠠᠶᠠᠨ "yellow"
🌞 sun ≈ shine šïŋarïn ʃɪŋarɪn shiñarᵒⁿ
🌞 sun ≈ jaune (yellow) ≈ 金 jīn (gold) ≈ ǧün ☼
🌞 sun ⇔ 黄 huáng 红 hóng 赤 chìⁿ
☼ sol ≈ gold keldaine⋍geld 🗸 𓐍 𓋴 𓋞 karaka "orange"
☼ sol ≈ swell
☼ hel ≈ hell (bright)
𒌓 UTU ≈ white ≈ bái 白 ≈ 日
𒌓 PAR PER PIR ≈ bright ≈ bái 白 ≈ 日
𒌓 PAR PER PIR ≈ purpur purple ?
𒌓 PAR PER PIR ≈ بردقاني burdʾāni "orange" ܦܘܼܪܬܩܵܠܵܐ purtqala @ portugal ƒ

𒍠 ZA₃ 𒍦 zib #şibbu צֶבַע zéva (color) √dye < √dip > ṣip Akkadian 𒍝𒁍𒌑 (/ṣabû/, “to soak, to bathe”) <> soup soap Arabic صَبَغَ ṣabaḡa, “to dye” Aramaic צְבַע ṣəbaʿ, “to dip, to dye” Ge'ez ጸብኀ ṣäbḫä, “to dip”
